This section will help users with quick fixes and solutions for common issues

Scanning is a process which may have multiple aspects that users may not take account when they start the scanning process. Each scanning may have different purpose such as indivual scans, scans with the purpose of merging or scans for colourising purpose. Indiidual scans can be considered as the simplest ones as the data-sets do not need to be combined directly with another data of any format, but rather for post-processing projects such as visualisation either 2D sections or layouts or 3D for collection information related to the geometry of the environment or the feature that is been scanned.


Individual scans

Is the process of collecting the geometry of 3D objects within an environment the user is in. It can capture free-form shapes and quickly generate a highly accurate 3D point cloud through a specialised software. The results appear - depending on the scan duration - in thousands or million of points representing the feature in 3D. Its purpose can be for inspection through the application software in PDF format report colouring deviations.


Merge multiple scans

Is the process of collecting multiple scans and register them to each other either in local or in any geodetic system. Key point in such scans is to have control points such as spherical targets or checkerboard targets based on which the registration process may be applied. The merging process can be devided into two parts. The rigid transformation (HUB & Draw) and the non-rigid transformation (HUB). The rigid transformation is based on control points where the user can apply in Draw by importing the coordinates of certain known targets (Draw); or move the point cloud (align close to the reference one) in the all 3 axis until the point clouds will meet (approximately) each other (HUB). Subsequently, the algorithm will apply the non-rigid transformation where it introcuces the matching feature algorithm automatically. In this part, it is very important for the user to have overlaps i.e. 30% so the algorithm can detect enough features for the registration purpose.


Scans for colourisation purpose

Is the process of collecting video in addition to point cloud for the purpose of either the colourisation or the combination of video next to 3D point cloud. The colourisation process is a bit different as the camera has smaller field of view compared to the laser scanner sensor. Hence, the user should point on different directions the device so the camera can collect frames of the same object from different point of views. The walking speed should also be sloewer compared to the individual scans.
